document.title: Complexification, complex structures, and linear ordinary differential equations

para.p: The solution of the initial value problem

Math.text: formulae@(x ^ prime * t = A * x * t, x * 0 = x _ 0 element-of R ^ n)

para.p:
where
A
is an
× n n
matrix over
R
, is
=
⁢ x
( t )
⁢
exp
(
⁢ A t
)
x 0
. If we want to compute the solution and if
A
is diagonalizable, say
= A
⁢ P D
P
- 1
, we use

Math.text: exponential@(A * t) = exponential@(P * D * P ^ (- 1) * t) = P * exponential@(D * t) * P ^ (- 1)

para.p:
Thus if the matrix
A
has complex eigenvalues, then although
∈
⁢
exp
(
⁢ A t
)
x 0
R n
, it may not be the case that
∈
⁢
P
- 1
x 0
R n
. For example, if
= A
(
0
- 1
1
0
)
, then

Math.text: formulae@(D = matrix[[- i, 0], [0, i]], formulae@(P = matrix[[- i, i], [1, 1]], P ^ (- 1) = (1 / 2) * matrix[[i, 1], [- i, 1]]))

para.p: This is similar to how Cardano’s formula, which expresses the roots of a real cubic polynomial in terms of its coefficients, involves complex numbers and yet the final result may still be real.

In the following, unless I specify the dimension of a vector space, any statement about real vector spaces is about real vector spaces of finite or infinite dimension, and any statement about complex vector spaces is about complex vector spaces of finite or infinite dimension.

If
V
is a real vector space, a complex structure for
V
is an
R
-linear map
: J
→ V V
such that
=
J 2
-
id V
.

If
V
is a real vector space and
: J
→ V V
is a complex structure, define a complex vector space
V J
in the following way: let the set of elements of
V J
be
V
, let addition in
V J
be addition in
V
, and define scalar multiplication in
V J
by

Math.text: (a + i * b) * v = a * v + b * J * v

para.p:
One checks that for
∈
α , β
C
and
∈ v
V J
we have
=

)
, and thus that
V J
is indeed a complex vector space with this definition of scalar multiplication. 1 footnote 1 1 footnote 1 One should also verify that distributivity holds with this definition of scalar product; the other properties of a vector space are satisfied because
V J
has the same addition as the real vector space
V
.

Let
V
be a real vector space, and define the
R
-linear map
: J
→
⊕ V V
⊕ V V
by

Math.text: J * open-interval@(v, w) = open-interval@(- w, v)

para.p:
=
J 2
-
id
⊕ V V
.
J
is a complex structure on the real vector space
⊕ V V
. The complexification of
V
is the complex vector space
=
V C
(
⊕ V V
)
J
. Thus,
V C
has the same set of elements as
⊕ V V
, the same addition as
⊕ V V
, and scalar multiplication

Math.text: (a + i * b) * open-interval@(v, w) = a * open-interval@(v, w) + b * J * open-interval@(v, w)

para.p: which gives

Math.text: (a + i * b) * open-interval@(v, w) = a * open-interval@(v, w) + b * open-interval@(- w, v) = open-interval@(a * v, a * w) + open-interval@(- b * w, b * v) = open-interval@(a * v - b * w, a * w + b * v)

para.p:
If the real vector space
V
has dimension
n
and if
{
e 1

e n
}
is a basis for
V

Math.text: set@(open-interval@(e _ 1, 0), ldots, open-interval@(e _ n, 0), open-interval@(0, e _ 1), ldots, open-interval@(0, e _ n))

para.p:
is a basis for the real vector space
⊕ V V

V C

Math.text: list@(a _ 1, ldots, a _ n, b _ 1, ldots, b _ n) element-of R

para.p: such that

Math.text: v = a _ 1 * open-interval@(e _ 1, 0) + cdots * a _ n * open-interval@(e _ n, 0) + b _ 1 * open-interval@(0, e _ 1) + cdots + b _ n * open-interval@(0, e _ n) = a _ 1 * open-interval@(e _ 1, 0) + cdots + a _ n * open-interval@(e _ n, 0) + b _ 1 * J * open-interval@(e _ 1, 0) + cdots + b _ n * J * open-interval@(e _ n, 0) = (a _ 1 + i * b _ 1) * open-interval@(e _ 1, 0) + cdots + (a _ n + i * b _ n) * open-interval@(e _ n, 0)
a _ 1 * open-interval@(e _ 1, 0) + cdots * a _ n * open-interval@(e _ n, 0) + b _ 1 * open-interval@(0, e _ 1) + cdots + b _ n * open-interval@(0, e _ n)
a _ 1 * open-interval@(e _ 1, 0) + cdots + a _ n * open-interval@(e _ n, 0) + b _ 1 * J * open-interval@(e _ 1, 0) + cdots + b _ n * J * open-interval@(e _ n, 0)
(a _ 1 + i * b _ 1) * open-interval@(e _ 1, 0) + cdots + (a _ n + i * b _ n) * open-interval@(e _ n, 0)

para.p:
where in the last line we used the definition of scalar multiplication in

Complexification is a functor from the category of real vector spaces to the category of complex vector spaces:

Math.text: ([id] _ V) ^ C * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2) = open-interval@([id] _ V * v _ 1, [id] _ V * v _ 2) = open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2) = [id] _ (V ^ C) * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2)

para.p:
so
=

Math.text: (T compose S) ^ C * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2) = open-interval@(T * S * v _ 1, T * S * v _ 2) = T ^ C * open-interval@(S * v _ 1, S * v _ 2) = T ^ C * S ^ C * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2)

para.p:

If
V
is a real vector space and
: J
→ V V

Math.text: formulae@(E _ i = conditional-set@(w element-of V ^ C, J ^ C * w = i * w), E _ (- i) = conditional-set@(w element-of V ^ C, J ^ C * w = - i * w))

para.p:
If
∈ w
V C

para.p: and
It follows that

Math.text: V ^ C = E _ i direct-sum E _ (- i)

section.title: 5Complex structures, inner products, and symplectic forms

para.p:
If
V
is a real vector space of odd dimension, then one can show that there is no linear map
: J
→ V V
satisfying
=
J 2
-
id V
, i.e. there does not exist a complex structure for it. On the other hand, if
V
has even dimension, let

Math.text: set@(e _ 1, ldots, e _ n, f _ 1, ldots, f _ n)

para.p:
be a basis for the real vector space
V
, and define
: J
→ V V
by

Math.text: formulae@(J * e _ j = f _ j, J * f _ j = - e _ j)

para.p:
Then
: J
→ V V
is a complex structure.

If
V
is a real vector space of dimension
⁢ 2 n
with a complex structure
J
, let
≠
e 1
0
. Check that
∉
⁢ J
e 1
⁢ span
{
e 1

Math.text: e _ 2 not-element-of [span] * set@(e _ 1, J * e _ 1)

is a basis for
V

Using the above basis

=

:

→

R
by

Math.text: formulae@(list@(e _ i, e _ j) = delta _ (list@(i, j)), formulae@(list@(f _ i, f _ j) = delta _ (list@(i, j)), formulae@(list@(e _ i, f _ j) = 0, list@(f _ i, e _ j) = 0)))

para.p:
Check that this is an inner product on the real vector space
V
. Moreover,

Math.text: list@(J * e _ i, J * e _ j) = list@(f _ i, f _ j) = delta _ (list@(i, j)) = list@(e _ i, e _ j)

para.p: and

Math.text: list@(J * f _ i, J * f _ j) = list@(J ^ 2 * e _ i, J ^ 2 * e _ j) = list@(- e _ i, - e _ j) = list@(e _ i, e _ j) = delta _ (list@(i, j)) = list@(f _ i, f _ j)

para.p: and

Math.text: list@(J * e _ i, J * f _ j) = list@(f _ i, - e _ j) = - list@(f _ i, e _ j) = 0 = list@(e _ i, f _ j)

para.p: and

Math.text: list@(J * f _ i, J * e _ j) = list@(- e _ i, f _ j) = - list@(e _ i, f _ j) = 0 = list@(f _ i, e _ j)

para.p:
Hence for any
∈
v , w
V
,

Math.text: list@(J * v, J * w) = list@(v, w)

para.p:
We say that the complex structure
J
is compatible with the inner product
⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩
, i.e.
: J
→
( V ,
⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩
)
( V ,
⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩
)
is an orthogonal transformation.

A symplectic form on a real vector space
V
is a bilinear form
: ω
→
× V V
R
such that
=
⁢ ω
( v , w )
-
⁢ ω
( w , v )
, and such that if
=
⁢ ω
( v , w )
0
for all
w
then
= v 0
; we say respectively that
ω
is skew-symmetric and non-degenerate. If a real vector space
V
has a complex structure
J
, and
⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩
is an inner product on
V
that is compatible with
J
, define
ω
by

Math.text: omega * open-interval@(v, w) = list@(v, J ^ (- 1) * w) = list@(v, - J * w) = - list@(v, J * w)

para.p: which is equivalent to

Math.text: omega * open-interval@(v, J * w) = list@(v, w)

para.p:
Using that the inner product is compatible with
J
and that it is symmetric,

Math.text: omega * open-interval@(v, w) = - list@(v, J * w) = - list@(J * v, J ^ 2 * w) = - list@(J * v, - w) = list@(w, J * v) = - omega * open-interval@(w, v)

para.p:
so
ω
is skew-symmetric. If
∈ w V
and
=
⁢ ω
( v , w )
0
for all
∈ v V
, then

Math.text: - list@(v, J * w) = 0

ω

ω

A basis

for a symplectic vector space that satisfies these three conditions is called a Darboux basis. We have

Math.text: omega * open-interval@(J * v, J * w) = - list@(J * v, J ^ 2 * w) = - list@(J ^ 2 * v, J ^ 3 * w) = - list@(- v, - J * w) = - list@(v, J * w) = omega * open-interval@(v, w)

para.p:
We say that
J
is compatible with the sympletic form
ω
, namely,
: J
→
( V , ω )
( V , ω )
is a symplectic transformation.

On the other hand, if
V
is a real vector space with symplectic form
ω
and
J
is a compatible complex structure, then
:
⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩
→
× V V
R
defined by

Math.text: list@(v, w) = omega * open-interval@(v, J * w)

para.p:
is an inner product on
V
that is compatible with the complex structure
J
.

Suppose
V
is a real vector space with complex structure
: J
→ V V
and that
: h
→
×
V J
V J
C

V J
. Define

→

R
by 4 footnote 4 4 footnote 4 The letter
h
refers to a Hermitian form, i.e. an inner product on a complex vector space, and the letter
g
refers to the usual notation for a metric on a Riemannian manifold.

Math.text: g * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2) = (1 / 2) * (h * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2) + overline@(h * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2))) = (1 / 2) * (h * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2) + h * open-interval@(v _ 2, v _ 1))

para.p:
It is straightforward to check that
g
is an inner product on the real vector space
V
. Similarly, define
: ω
→
× V V
R
by

Math.text: omega * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2) = (i / 2) * (h * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2) - overline@(h * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2))) = (i / 2) * (h * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2) - h * open-interval@(v _ 2, v _ 1))

para.p:
It is apparent that
ω
is skew-symmetric. If
=

(

0

As
h
is a complex inner product,

para.p:
which writes the inner product on the complex vector space
V J

V

omega * open-interval@(v _ 1, J * v _ 2)
(i / 2) * (h * open-interval@(v _ 1, J * v _ 2) - h * open-interval@(J * v _ 2, v _ 1))

g * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2)

para.p:
Here we give another presentation of the complexification of a real vector space, this time using tensor products of real vector spaces. If you were satisfied by the first definition you don’t need to read this one; read this either if you are curious about another way to define complexification, if you want to see a pleasant application of tensor products, or if you didn’t like the first definition. Let
V
be a real vector space of dimension
n
.
C
is a real vector space of dimension
2
, and

Math.text: V tensor-product _ R C

para.p:
is a real vector space of dimension
⁢ 2 n
. If
V
has basis
{
e 1
, … ,
e n
}
, then
⊗ R
V C
has basis
{
⊗
e 1
1
, … ,
⊗
e n
1
,
⊗
e 1
i
, … ,
⊗
e n
i
}
. Since every element of
⊗ R
V C
can be written uniquely in the form

Math.text: list@(v _ 1 tensor-product 1 + v _ 2 tensor-product i, v _ 1, v _ 2) element-of V

para.p: one often writes

Math.text: V tensor-product _ R C approximately-equals V direct-sum i * V

para.p:
here
⁢ i V
is a real vector space that is isomorphic to
V
.

The complexification of
V
is the complex vector space
V C
whose set of elements is
⊗ R
V C
, with the same addition as the real vector space
⊗ R
V C
, and with scalar multiplication defined by

Math.text: formulae@(alpha * (v tensor-product beta) = v tensor-product (alpha * beta), formulae@(v element-of list@(V, alpha), beta element-of C))

para.p:
Let
∈ v
V C
. Using the basis of the real vector space
⊗ R
V C
, there exist some

Math.text: list@(a _ 1, ldots, a _ n, b _ 1, ldots, b _ n) element-of R

para.p: such that

Math.text: v = (a _ 1 * e _ 1) tensor-product 1 + cdots + (a _ n * e _ n) tensor-product 1 + (b _ 1 * e _ 1) tensor-product i + cdots + (b _ n * e _ n) tensor-product i = e _ 1 tensor-product (a _ 1 + i * b _ 1) + cdots + e _ n tensor-product (a _ n + i * b _ n) = ((a _ 1 + i * b _ 1) * e _ 1) tensor-product 1 + cdots + ((a _ n + i * b _ n) * e _ n) tensor-product 1
(a _ 1 * e _ 1) tensor-product 1 + cdots + (a _ n * e _ n) tensor-product 1 + (b _ 1 * e _ 1) tensor-product i + cdots + (b _ n * e _ n) tensor-product i
e _ 1 tensor-product (a _ 1 + i * b _ 1) + cdots + e _ n tensor-product (a _ n + i * b _ n)
((a _ 1 + i * b _ 1) * e _ 1) tensor-product 1 + cdots + ((a _ n + i * b _ n) * e _ n) tensor-product 1

para.p:
where in the last line we used the definition of scalar multiplication in
V C
. One checks that the
{
⊗
e 1
1
, … ,
⊗
e n
1
}
is linearly independent over
C
, and hence that it is a basis for the complex vector space
V C
, so
V C
has dimension
n
over
C
.

If
V
and
W
are real vector spaces and
: T
→ V W
is a linear map, define
:
T C
→
V C
W C
by

Math.text: T ^ C * (v tensor-product z) = (T * v) tensor-product z

para.p:
With this definition of
T C
, one can check that complexification is a functor from the category of real vector spaces to the category of complex vector spaces.

If
V
is a complex vector space, let
V R
be the real vector space whose set of elements is
V
, in which addition is the same as addition in
V
, and in which scalar multiplication is defined by

Math.text: formulae@(a * v = (a + 0 * i) * v, a element-of R)

para.p:
Because
V
is a complex vector space, it is apparent that
V R
is a real vector space with this scalar multiplication. We call
V R
the decomplexification of the complex vector space

para.p:
If

: T

para.p:
Because

C

T R
is
R
-linear. Decomplexification is a functor from the category of complex vector spaces to the category of real vector spaces. Since decomplexification is defined simply by ignoring the fact that
V
is closed under multiplication by complex scalars and only using real scalars, decomplexification is called a forgetful functor

. In words, a linear map on the complexification of a real vector space is equal to its own conjugate if and only if it is the complexification of a linear map on the real vector space.

We have

Math.text: (alpha + i * omega) * open-interval@(v _ 1, v _ 2) = open-interval@(alpha * v _ 1 - omega * v _ 2, alpha * v _ 1 + omega * v _ 2)

para.p: and

Math.tex: Av_{1}=\alpha v_{1}-\omega v_{2},\qquad Av_{2}=\alpha v_{1}+\omega v_{2},
Math.text: formulae@(A * v _ 1 = alpha * v _ 1 - omega * v _ 2, A * v _ 2 = alpha * v _ 1 + omega * v _ 2)

para.p: and hence

Math.text: A * matrix[[v _ 1, v _ 2]] = matrix[[alpha * v _ 1 - omega * v _ 2, alpha * v _ 1 + omega * v _ 2]] = matrix[[v _ 1, v _ 2]] * matrix[[alpha, omega], [- omega, alpha]]

para.p: Therefore

Math.text: A = matrix[[v _ 1, v _ 2]] * matrix[[alpha, omega], [- omega, alpha]] * matrix[[v _ 1, v _ 2]] ^ (- 1)
